chapter.title: References
chapter.para: Brian Marick (a judge in both rounds of the Software Carpentry design competition) is the author of a thorough survey of the art called The Craft of Software Testing. Many of his other writings are available on-line at: http://www.testing.com
Testing Computer Software, by Cem Kaner, Hung Quoc Nguyen, and Jack Falk, is a good look at testing in the real world.

The Pragmatic Programmer, by Andy Hunt and Dave Thomas (both judges in the Software Carpentry design competition), includes a lot of good material on when and how to test during development. The book's web site is at: http://www.pragmaticprogrammer.com

The Visualization Toolkit</ulink project places a lot of emphasis on testing, and has a well-developed framework for doing it systematically. This is described in the paper at ftp://www.visualizationtoolkit.org/pub/vtk/ExtremeTestingPaper.pdf.

Some existing testing tools used in Open Source development include:
Expect http://expect.nist.gov/
DejaGnu http://www.gnu.org/software/dejagnu/dejagnu.html
TET
http://tetworks.opengroup.org/

The FAQ for comp.software.testing is available at:
http://www.landfield.com/faqs/software-eng/testing-faq/.

The Visualization Toolkit (VTK) stands out among large Open Source projects for the amount and thoroughness of its testing. The procedures VTK uses are described in a paper by William Lorensen and James Miller, which is available on-line at:
ftp://www.visualizationtoolkit.org/pub/vtk/ExtremeTestingPaper.pdf

Highlights from the ≻ discussion list are summarized at:
http://www.software-carpentry.com/sc_test/#highlights. The entire discussion list is archived at: http://www.software-carpentry.com/lists/sc-discuss/maillist.html
James Bach's paper Test Automation Snake Oil discusses why full automation of testing is not possible, practical, or desirable: http://www.satisfice.com/articles/test_automation_snake_oil.pdf
